Visual analytics  provides visual and interactive tools to support analytical reasoning and for finding insight from data. It combines the human capabilities to interpret visualizations with automatic data processing. A visual analytics tool shows the information in the form of interconnected  and  interactive  visualizations.  Behind the visualizations are statistical, data mining and machine learning methods. Users can look for patterns, trends, anomalies, similarities and other relevant features from the visualizations. Visual analytics is an iterative process where users launch analysis, browse and navigate in visualizations, and highlight and select important areas for further study. 
VTT Open VA platform consist of software components that are used as building blocks of visual analytics tools:
• A database that stores the application data in a standard domain independent form
• An extendable analysis and visualization library providing a selection of analysis and visualization methods. The library is customized based on application needs
•  Analysis framework for running different analysis methods
• A web user interface where the user can select variables for analysis  and explore the data with the help of visualizations. The user interface suggests the user the appropriate analysis methods letting them to concentrate on the substance instead of data analysis methods.

VTT OpenVA is independent of the underlying data collection solution. The data can come from several sources, also in real time. The data to be analyzed is loaded from the sources to the database through a uniform data interface.
Current SQL database -> future Hadoop data

Framework for visual analytics of measurement data 
http://www.thinkmind.org/index.php?view=article&art icleid=infocomp_2013_3_10_10030 
Järvinen, Paula; Siltanen, Pekka; Rainio, Kari
3rd International Conference on Advanced Communications and Computation, INFOCOMP 2013, 17 - 22 November 2013, Lisbon, Portugal

ADAE provides tools for detecting anomalies, like faults, intrusions, errors, outliers, novelties and defects. It is based on a data analysis pipeline. The anomalies are detected by describing the data (e.g. time series) with multiple mathematical models and deciding by voting. The benefits are:  1) No need for expensive modifications/integrations of the existing systems or environments and 2) Ability to automatically, immediately and accurately discover the important information in the data. Technically it is a Python package
Anomalies, outliers, data analysis, anomaly detection, diagnostics, data modelling
ADAE - Anomaly Detection Data Analysis Engine
Alvar Mobile: Android, iOS, Windows Phone, Alvar Desktop: Linux, Windows, Mac

ALVAR is a suite of products and SDKs for creating augmented reality applications. ALVAR provides leading tracking technology that can be leveraged to add value to products and services, solve industrial problems and enable next generation tools. ALVAR customers include software developers, major product manufacturers as well as corporate users.
ALVAR is "a library for virtual and augmented reality." The ALVAR SDK allows you to create AR applications with the most accurate, efficient and robust implementation for marker-, 2D image-, and 3D point cloud-based tracking. ALVAR provides a low-level C++ API to its tracking algorithms and includes several tools that assist in the creation of AR applications. Its low-level interface makes it possible to develop custom solutions that can be integrated with existing products and services.
ALVAR 2D SDK
Features: Tracks 2D targets, markers and images; Accurate, fast and robust, also handles occlusions; Pose optimization and perspective projection; Multi-marker tracking with automatic calibration; Image matching and template-based tracking; Diminished reality
ALVAR 3D SDK
Features: Markerless, feature-based 3D tracking; Based on point clouds created from photos of target; Most accurate, fast and reliable 3D tracking available; Automatic initialization without user interaction; Robust against occlusions, changes in environment, lighting conditions; Covers wide areas, dynamic loading of point clouds, optimal performance using edge servers; Panorama tracking with semi-automatic initialization; Extended tracking, SLAM, sensor fusion
ALVAR Studio
Features: Unity-based AR content authoring platform; Support for animated 3D models, images, annotations; Align AR content with tracking targets, markers, images, point clouds; Various tools for point cloud editing and optimization
Alvar Mobile: VTT Licence, Alvar Desktop: LGPL 3
Software development toolkit for different platforms

Digital service registry provides a framework to implement multi-organization, service oriented ICT solution and offering integrations and interworking rapidly based on business needs of the collaborating organizations.  VTT Digital Services Hub provides a working instance of the registry. The Service Registry Framework (backend without UI) is available as open source.

TRL-7  readiness is for the reference implementation and its data model API which is targeted to Energy domain. For DataBio most relevant parts are the service & knowledge models defining the knowledge interoperability core model in reference implementation. Those may be used separately of energy vocabulary and ideas from development branch migrated to allow extending knowledge model to DataBio domains.

SEAS Knowledge Model defines  knowledge and service models containing a  domain independent knowledge exchange interoperability core that is supported with energy-awareness related vocabularies for smart grid, smart home and smart vechicle applications. Knowledge model is supported by a reference implementation providing service oriented data exchange architecture and API targeted to support exchanging energy information from IoT to business & market level.
Reference implementation: http://seas.asema.com/,   energy system and process modeling related devekionebt branch at https://github.com/thesmartenergy/seas
Knowledge model, Service model, Knowledge Interoperability, Energy domain
Java, C#, Javascript, Phyton API library, OWL2/Turtle vocabulary

The Metrics Visualization System (MVS) is a tool for designing and monitoring the security of information systems. In order to make a more objective assessment of the security performance of such systems, one needs to measure them systematically. Better evidence makes it easier to dynamically address security threats. Furthermore, designing new systems can benefit from earlier security measuring efforts, and thus a tool capable of reusing compatible parts can repay the effort of its commissioning
< e.g. web link to running instance of  service / software download site>

The security metric model  consists of different types of security metric nodes, e.g., security controls or measurement probes. The ontology for the MVS describes the concepts and relationships needed to construct and use a security metric model in the MVS. The model is written in Turtle, which is a shorthand notation for expressing data in an RDF model.
Java based UI , REST based security probe interface
Details given by the contact point

The security model is represented in UI by a tree-like graph. For run-time visualizations we have implemented a traffic-light color scheme, where red denotes an insufficient, yellow intermediate and green sufficient security level for a node. Different node types are presented with different vertex shapes. One can also calculate the value of a higher-level metric from the values of its child nodes.
< e.g. web link to component documentation>
Linux/Windows. GDAL required, and for the GUI(s) also Java Runtime Environment.

Probability is a software package for predicting (forest) variables. It covers both continuous-valued variables (e.g. tree cover density, stem volume) and category type variables (e.g. land cover classes). The complete Probability processing chain consists of five individual software components (+ Mosaic, a VTT tool as well). Also available are the GUIs Proba Workflow Manager and Proba Batch Manager. Both interactive and batch modes of operation are supported.
By request from VTT. In planning, access via Forestry TEP.
Image files in any GDAL supported format. Reference data formats: field plot data, estimates image or feature bank data as table-formatted ASCII; stand variable data as shape files.
Command-line interface/scripts + two GUIs. WPS interface in planning.
Estimate image in GDAL supported formats, e.g. GeoTIFF. Modelling data in specific ASCII formats.
Accepts ESA SAFE format Sentinel-2 L1C files, Windows and Unix

Alternativelly, FMI may provide its in-house Python-based processing chain for spatio-temporal analysis (time series of L2 products reduced to L3 best-quality image)
Linux/Windows. Requirements include GDAL, Shapefile C Library (http://shapelib.maptools.org/).

Envimon is a set of satellite data preprocessing tools for data unpacking, radiometric corrections (top-of-atmosphere and bottom-of-atmosphere reflectances) and geometric corrections including ortho-rectification. Both interactive and batch modes of operation are supported.
By request from VTT. In planning, access via Forestry TEP.
Unpacked raw satellite (optical or SAR) data package. Optional DEM data in image file for radiometric/geometric correction.
Command-line interface/scripts + GUI for MS Windows. WPS interface in planning.

The EAF portal is easily navigable and user-friendly rendering the data analysis readable and comprehensible to non-experts.
WebHDFS is a REST API that is used to upload a file into Hadoop cluster.
A multi-node Hadoop cluster provides the utilities for the post-processing, indexing, querying and visualization of the data.
Hive data warehouse software facilitates reading, writing, and managing large datasets residing in distributed storage using SQL.
Oozie is a Workflow scheduler system in which various Hadoop jobs can be pipelined in the desired order.
Impala is a Massively Parallel Processing (MPP) analytic database on top of Hadoop that pushes data processing down to local data nodes, avoiding network bottlenecks. Thanks to these architectural advantages, Impala enables low-latency/interactive queries to data stored in HDFS, especially under multi-user load.
Batch processing, Streaming processing, Privacy-preserving processing, Anonymisation

Cybernetica UXP(R) is a framework for establishing secure data exchange between organizations. UXP ensures confidentiality of the exchanged data as well as creates proof value for all the transactions using digital signatures and timestamps. It supports federation between different instances, making it easy to develop cross-border digital services. Depending on circumstances, UXP can be used either countrywide (see the current implementations), in a local government, on a ministry-level or in a vertical domain (vertical community of organizations). See C35.01_01.pdf for additional information.
Interoperability Platform, X-Road, Cross-Border Services, Long-Term Proof Value

Apache Tomcat (open-source)
RDBMS PostgreSQL 9.0+ with spatial extension PostGIS 2.0+ and deployed SensLog data model

SensLog is web-based sensor data management application. This component provides receiving, storing, pre-processing and publishing of sensor data. SensLog is suitable for numeric or textual sensor data from static in-situ or mobile sensors and is also suitable for storing Volunteered geographic information (VGI) with connected multimedia files.
SensLog stores sensor data in own data model implemented in RDBMS with spatial extension. Data model is based on OGC Observations&Measurements standard but it is extended by alerts, group management, and improved by mechanism of partitioning. Data model is designed as extensible from very beginning. 
SensLog is modular solution and it consists of several modules at current version. SensLog provides RESTful API for most of modules and OGC SOS core services for publishing of stored data.
This component is deployed on an application server (Tomcat).
OpenLayers 3.X, Core of framework is developed using AngularJS, requireJS and Bootstrap

HSLayers NG is a web mapping library written in Javascript. It extends OpenLayers 3 functionality and takes basic ideas from the previous HSLayers library, but uses modern JS frameworks instead of ExtJS 3 at the frontend and provides better adaptability. That’s why the NG (“Next Generation”) is added to its name. It is still under development and provided as open source. HSLayers is built in a modular way which enables the modules to be freely attached and removed as far as the dependencies for each of them are satisfied. The dependency checking is done automatically.
WMS, WFS, WCS, SOS, KML, GeJSON, RDF, …

Farm Telemetry is web-based data management and analytical application for economy and effectiveness analysis for farms. This application processes tracking data from agricultural machinery, agro-meteo stations and evidence of activities on farms.
Farm Telemetry uses data from Foodie data model, LPIS, cadastral data, Yield potential etc. This component uses parts of SensLog data model. Analytical functions are implemented in RDBMS in PL/SQL. Publication of data is provided by REST services. Graphical user inteface is based on portlet in Liferay, uses charts based on D3.js and maps based on HSLayersNG.

WebGLayer is a JavaScript library focused on fast interactive visualization of big multidimensional spatial data through linked views. The library is based on WebGL and uses GPU for fast rendering and filtering. Using commodity hardware the library can visualize hundreds of thousand of features with several attributes through heatmap, point symbol map. Users thus benefit from immediate and dynamic data visualizations, gain better understanding of data by applying filters, and develop the opportunity to discover relationships and patterns in the data.
The library can render the data on the map provided by third party libraries (e.g. OpenLayers, Leaflet, GoogleMap API).
The supported visualization techniques in v1.2.0 are:
• Histograms (rendered by d3.js)
• Point Symbol map (rendered by WebGL)
• Heat map (rendered by WebGL)
• Parallel coordinates (rendered by WebGL)
The library supports interactions:
• Filter by attribute (brush&link)
• Filter by polygon (polybrush)
• Filter by color of a heatmap (in order to select a hotspot)
More required visualization features or outputs can be added if needed.

JavaScript library
Can be used as core framework for web browser visualization.

Open data model for (precision) agriculture applications and agricultural pollution monitoring was developed in the EU 7FP project called "FOODIE" (http://foodie-project.eu/). Such model was also registered under the GEOSS (Global Earth Observation System of Systems) Architecture Implementation Pilot – Phase 8 in order to support the wide variety of demands that are primary aimed at agriculture and water pollution monitoring. Moreover, geographic information UML models were transformed into OWL ontologies defined by the ISO 19150-2 standard.
linked data; semantics; agriculture; INSPIRE; OWL
UML data model and OWL ontologies

GeoRocket is a high-performance data store for geospatial files. It can store 3D city models (e.g. CityGML), GML files or GeoJSON data sets.

GeoRocket provides the following features:

• High performance data storage with multiple back-ends such as Amazon S3, MongoDB, distributed file systems (e.g. HDFS or Ceph), or your local hard drive (enabled by default)
• Support for high-speed search features based on the popular Open-Source framework Elasticsearch. You can perform spatial queries and search for attributes, layers and tags.
• GeoRocket is made for the Cloud. Based on the Open-Source toolkit Vert.x it is reactive and can handle big files and a large number of parallel requests.

GeoRocket’s architecture allows for the creation of secondary data stores that co-exist with the main data store. The advantage of keeping a secondary data store is that it allows to generate or derive additional information automatically when new data is added.

GeoRocket consists of two components: the server and the command-line interface (CLI).
Data Storage, Cloud, Big Data, Metadata

• XML
• GML/CityGML
• GeoJSON
• Any generated or derived information from the secondary data store

The JobManager allows to orchestrate existing tools and algorithms to be executed in a distributed way. The main advantage is that it supports arbitrary processing services implemented in different programming languages or frameworks, compared to other orchestration frameworks which require specific interfaces.
A Domain Specific Language (DSL) can be used to describe workflows to process the data without in-depth knowledge about the services and their interfaces. Based on this, the JobManager makes decisions on the required services and resources along with a strategy to split and distribute input data. While executing a workflow, the JobManager monitors the processing to call subsequent services.
To allow uniform data access, the modular architecture of the JobManager allows to use different distributed filesystems or object storage technologies.
Interface for importing quality control data into METSAK's internal systems.
No existing instances for this interface
Interface for importing quality control data
The DataGraft tool can support the publication of data into linked data, and also support various types of data curation and transformation - for all of the pilots

DataGraft is a data preparation, curation, transformation, linking and publishing tool.  It accepts that input in various table formats and CSV, and allows for data cleaning and transformation operations into a new CSV, table form - or into linked data / RDF  - where it also can support the serving of linked data as a service  - hosting the data in a Data as a service platform.

Rasdaman is an open source array database system, which provides flexible, fast, scalable geo services for multi-dimensional spatio-temporal sensor, image, simulation, and statistics data of unlimited volume. 
Data is stored in a PostgreSQL database, thereby achieving full information integration (e.g., latitudes, longitudes, time coordinates, resolutions and other ancillary annotations.).
Ad-hoc access, extraction, aggregation, as well as remix and analytics is enabled through a new SQL raster query language - the rasdaman Query Language (RasQL)- with highly effective server-side optimization.
The core Features include
• truly multi-dimensional - 1-D, 2-D, 3-D, 4-D, and beyond
• powerful, flexible query language for visualization, classification, convolution, aggregation, and many more geospatial functions
• spatial indexing and adaptive tiling for fast data access
• parallelization and “tile streaming” for unlimited scalability from laptop to cluster and cloud
• full information integration of raster data with all geo data in the PostgreSQL database
• support for the raster-relevant OGC standards, Reference Implementation for WCS Core and WCPS

Implemented standards (through the Petascope component):
• OGC WMS 1.3.0
• WCS 2.0
• WCS-T 1.4
• WCPS 1.0
• WPS 1.0
Rasdaman architecture is depicted in the next figure.

• Rasdaman: http://www.rasdaman.org/
• OpenGIS Web Map Service (WMS) Implementation Specification  1.3.0 (document reference 06-042): http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=14416
• OGC WCS 2.0 Interface Standard - Core, version 2.0.1 (document reference 09-110r4): https://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/09-110r4
• OGC Web Coverage Service Interface Standard – Transaction Extension 2.0 (document reference 13-057r1): http://docs.opengeospatial.org/is/13-057r1/13-057r1.html
• OpenGIS Web Coverage Processing Service (WCPS) Language Interface Standard 1.0.0 (document reference 08-068r2): http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=32319
• Web Processing Service 1.0.0 (document reference 05-007r7): http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=24151

Storm is a complex event processor (CEP) and distributed computation framework written predominantly in the Clojure programming language. Is a distributed real-time computation system for processing fast, large streams of data. Storm is an architecture based on master-workers paradigma. So a Storm cluster mainly consists of a master and worker nodes, with coordination done by Zookeeper.
Ruby, Python, Javascript, Perl, stdin/stdout JSON based protocol, REST

Flume is a distributed, reliable, and available service for efficiently collecting, aggregating, and moving large amounts of log data. It has a simple and flexible architecture based on streaming data flows. It is robust and fault tolerant with tunable reliability mechanisms and many failover and recovery mechanisms. It uses a simple extensible data model that allows for online analytic application.
collecting, aggregating, moving large amounts of streaming event data
Runs on Proba-V MEP which is deployed at VITO
Proba-V Mission Exploitation Platform (MEP) containing a prototype processing chain to apply the Kalman filter on Proba-V and Sentinel-2 data for limited AOI
required: OS Linux - Centos7 ; optional: YARN, Mesos, HDFS, Hive, Hbase, Cassandra, Kafka

Data analytics cluster computing framework originally developed in the AMPLab at UC Berkeley. Spark fits into the Hadoop open-source community, building on top of the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS). However, Spark provides an easier to use alternative to Hadoop MapReduce and offers performance up to 10 times faster than previous generation systems like Hadoop MapReduce for certain applications.
Spark is a framework for writing fast, distributed programs. Spark solves similar problems as Hadoop MapReduce does but with a fast in-memory approach and a clean functional style API. With its ability to integrate with Hadoop and inbuilt tools for interactive query analysis (Shark), large-scale graph processing and analysis (Bagel), and real-time analysis (Spark Streaming), it can be interactively used to quickly process and query big data sets.
APIs in Scala, Java and Python, R; Command Line Interfece
Spark Streaming, Spark SQL, Spark Mllib - Machnie Learning, Spark GraphX, SparkR
required: OS Linux - Centos7; optional: Hive, Spark, Shell, HDFS

Oozie is a workflow scheduler system to manage Apache Hadoop jobs. Workflows in Oozie are defined as a collection of control flow and action nodes in a directed acyclic graph. Control flow nodes define the beginning and the end of a workflow (start, end and failure nodes) as well as a mechanism to control the workflow execution path (decision, fork and join nodes). Action nodes are the mechanism by which a workflow triggers the execution of a computation/processing task. Oozie provides support for different types of actions including Hadoop MapReduce, Hadoop distributed file system operations, Pig, SSH, and email.
API Java, REST; Command Line Interface
required: OS Linux - Centos7, Zookeeper, Thrift, HDFS; optional: SPARK

Distributed key/value store is a robust, scalable, high performance data storage and retrieval system. Apache Accumulo is based on Google's BigTable design and is built on top of Apache Hadoop, Zookeeper, and Thrift.

Distributed publish-subscribe system for processing large amounts of streaming data. Kafka is a Message Queue developed by LinkedIn that persists messages to disk in a very performant manner. SmartVis3D is a visualization component from Fraunhofer IGD. It supports the visualization of massive heterogenous geodata in a web browser. SmartVis3D comes along with tools from the GeoToolbox to transform the standard geoformats into renderable and hostable data for SmartVis3D. These services can be executed as command line applications or deployed as web services to the cloud.

The e-GEOS EO processing service is an architecture which is used to perform EO image processing from pre-processing steps to final information extraction. It works with following interfaces:
• REST (all data/parameters sent to a Job using POST)
• FTP (data transferred using FTP and parameters sent to a Job using POST)
It can distribute jobs on commodity HW using agent architecture.
The processing includes several steps with different purposes such as:
• Data retrieval: Sentinel, Landsat, MODIS  and other data download based on typical use cases (e.g. AOI and time range). Support also generic FTP transfer for traditional commercial EO data provision.
• Data preprocessing:
o Optical data: atmospheric correction, cloud detection, cloud-free mosaic generation
o SAR data: coregistration, coherence, multi-temporal coherence, interferometric map, segmentation
• Feature extraction:
o Optical: classification, feature extraction, band calculation to provide spectral indexes
o SAR data: ship detection, oil detection, flood detection
Pilots can submit their needs in terms of AOI and time range and then get base layers (e.g. change detection for forest monitoring, ship detection for fishery monitoring in natural areas) to integrate with other data into their business case.
Internal instance running on several thousands of km2 of Landsat/Sentinel 2 data and on millions of km2 of SAR data Sentinel 1
SaaS SAR processing, SaaS Optical processing, Cloud detection, Atmospheric Correction
MIT + e-GEOS IPR for processing algorithms

IoT Hub is a middleware component to support continuous data collection from IoT based resources. In a typical IT infrastructure, it is usually located at gateway level, between data producers (resources) and data consumers. One of its main features is that it can be deployed in low level devices, like Raspberry PI. Other general characteristics of the component are:
• Interoperability, by supporting well-known and most common protocols for IoT related data sources.
• Scalability, due the amount of data generated by IoT devices, the module’s performance behavior should remain stable during its use, being able to react to different data loads situations.
• Easy-to-use and install, simplifying the communication between uses cases and platform.
• Take advantage of the use of Open Sources technologies.

The IoT Hub is composed by a set of four sub-components that tackle three different issues: communication, management of the devices and handling of data. 
• Communication: grating interoperability and adaptation between different protocols and the matching between consumers and providers of data. 
• Device Management functionalities to enclose generic information about devices and also to address their security and connectivity.
• Supporting data handling functionalities, IoT Hub is also granted with a sub component that ensures that the data obtained in the IoT world is pre-filtered before being passed to a data consumer or platform, reducing the flow or the quantity of inaccurate data.

Supports the following interfaces:
• MQTT
• CoAP
• RabbitMQ
• HTTP
• Websockets
• Socket.io
IoT high-level architecture is depicted in the next figure:
Data Collector from heterogeneous resources with data handling functionalities

• FIWARE Generic Enablers https://catalogue.fiware.org/enablers 
• Backend Device Management https://catalogue.fiware.org/enablers/backend-device-management-idas 
• IoT Data Edge Consolidation GE https://catalogue.fiware.org/enablers/iot-data-edge-consolidation-ge-cepheus 
• EsperTech http://www.espertech.com/
Accepts ESA SAFE format Sentinel-1 L1C files, Windows and Unix

The GeoToolbox is a set of microservices for the processing of large geospatial data. Each microservice is responsible for a specific processing algorithm. Many services can be connected so that complete processing workflows can be created. Some examples for microservices from the GeoToolbox are as follows:

• Triangulation (Delaunay)
• Resampling
• Colorization
• Pre-processing for 3D web visualization
• Data conversion

The services can be executed as command line applications or deployed as web services to the cloud. They can therefore be integrated easily in existing applications and infrastructures.

The GeoToolbox supports a number of input and output formats ranging from terrain models and 3D city models to shapefiles and orthophotos.

• GML/CityGML
• Shapefile
• GeoTIFF
• XYZ
• ESRI TIN/ESRI TerrainGrid
• ASCII TerrainGrid
• DXF
• VRML

• GML/CityGML
• Shapefile

• ASCII TerrainGrid
• VRML/X3D
• COLLADA/KML
• glTF

Can be used in combination with the FedEO Gateway and FedEO Catalog to setup a complete chain to retrieve and catalog Sentinel-1, Sentinel-2 or Landsat data (SciHub and CMR/USGS) and other data available through FedEO on a local processing platform.

This component is deployed on an application server (GlashFish).  It can be invoked to perform discovery of EO data (via OGC 13-026r8, e.g. through a FedEO Gateway instance), download of these data, optional invocation of processing) and registration of the data in a cache.  The downloaded/converted EO data is copied to local stores (NFS or HDFS) where they are accessed by the processing chain(s) (execution environment).

The download is performed by a third-party Download Mgr subcomponent which is currently being replaced by an open-source alternative.  HTTP and FTP downloads will be supported.

Access to Sentinel s Scientific Data Hub (https://scihub.copernicus.eu/) will be supported.   Access to Landsat data would require the development of a dedicated plugin to access download URL on USGS Web pages.

The component offers a RESTful API and a Java API.
< e.g. web link to running instance of  service / software download site>

Provided interfaces: • RESTful API
•  Java API

Both interfaces allow a client to define (as a catalog query) the list of products to be downloaded.
An ArchiMate  representation of the provided and required interfaces is depicted in the MS-Word description. See also - OGC 13-026r8, http://docs.opengeospatial.org/is/13-026r8/13-026r8.html
EO Product Discovery, Cache, Download, ESA

open-source

The component is the result of an ongoing ESA/VITO project (2016-2018) and will eventually be published as open-source.

Required interfaces:• Access to file system (HDFS, NFS) to store downloaded data
• Access to execution environment (invoke (pre)processing chain)
• Write access to OGC 13-026r8 catalog (to store metadata of downloaded products).  Metadata from catalog to include product download URL as atom:link ("enclosure").
• HTTP access to product to be downloaded from product facilities, multiple files via Metalink.

Can be used in combination with the FedEO Gateway and Data Manager to setup a complete chain to retrieve and catalog Sentinel-1, Sentinel-2 or Landsat data and other data available through FedEO on a local processing platform.

This component is deployed on an application server (Tomcat) and implements a catalog server allowing to store EO (satellite) collections (series) and products (datasets) metadata.  It offers an API to populate the catalog and an API to search the catalog.  

The search interface is compliant with OpenSearch, OGC 10-32r8 and OGC 13-026r8.  The transactional interface (to populate the catalog) is compliant with W3C LDP 1.0 RESTful conventions.

The following types of metadata are currently supported:
- ISO19139
- OGC 10-157r4

Can be accessed by any client application implementing the API.  
Various tools to populate the catalog starting from index-files (CSV) exist as well.

This catalog implementation is operational at ESA as the FedEO Collection Catalog (Tomcat, RedHat Linux, CentOS Linux).  The FedEO Dataset Catalog is an evolution which will be operational from March 2017 onwards.
Installed at Spacebel and ESA/ESRIN (behind FedEO Gateway at fedeo.esa.int and geo.spacebel.be).

This component (Web API) can be deployed on an application server (Tomcat) and provides a unique standard-based access point (service) for discovery of EO (satellite) collections (series) and products (datasets) using Linked Data principles.  It can be configured to access remote services implementing various protocols including OGC CSW flavours, REST API or other.  It converts the standard protocols (OGC 10-032r8, OGC 13-026r8) into protocols understood by the backend services/ and returns standard output (e.g. RDF/XML, JSON-LD, Turtle) with download URL if available.

Can be configured to access Sentinel data (Scientific Sentinels Data Hub), VITO Proba-V, and Landsat and other missions.  An installation of this component is available at Spacebel (http://obeos.spacebel.be/opensearch/readme.html) and ESA (http://obeos.esa.int/opensearch/readme.html).  Dedicated installation could be done for DataBio and additional backends could be added if made available.

Allows applications to use a single protocol for discovery and access for various missions from different providers.

Provides an SRU-like API and a RESTful API.  The RESTful API is compliant with W3C LDP 1.0.  The RDF output is defined in OGC 16-074.
Additional response formats and metadata formats are available and more can be added.  The available RDF output can be extended if needed.

Can be accessed by any client application implementing the API to search for EO collections or products matching certain criteria (e.g. bounding box, time constraints etc.).
Installed at Spacebel and ESA/ESRIN (http://obeos.spacebel.be/opensearch/readme.html, obeos.esa.int/opensearch/readme.html).

Delivers crucial information to growers and researchers in an easy-to-use interface. Allows import data files from other applications and plot graphs quickly and easily. Sets sensor alarms that call your phone or pager for frost, rainfall and other conditions.  Customizes and saves your important reports. Requires Windows 98 or later, and one free USB port (Serial ports are still supported for existing serial cables). Can offer insect and disease models to forecast pest pressures and reduce pesticide costs; produces reports with graphs for each pest. Alarm can be set that will call mobile phone or pager at specific sensor conditions. Allows for automate logger downloads with wireless or directly connected stations. Generates scheduled log files for data-to-web applications or creates an XML file that can be posted on the web. All logger data is stored in one file per month, simplifying data sharing and exporting. Allows import data files from other applications. It is compatible with Windows 98, XP, Vista, 7, 8, and 10.

The OpenLink Virtuoso (open source edition of Virtuoso Universal Server) is a middleware and database engine hybrid that combines the functionality of a traditional RDBMS, ORDBMS, virtual database, RDF, XML, free-text content management & full-text indexing, linked data server, web application server and file server functionality in a single system. In DATABIO we are mainly interested in the RDF store for the provisioning of a semantic database (triplestore) as a service for the storage of RDF data, as well as for their publication as linked data. 
Regarding Virtuoso RDF, key features include: an RDF triple store, SPARQL query language support, SPARQL pro-tocol support, inline SPARQL integration within SQL, use of bitmap indices for optimizing storage and management of RDF triples, implementation of the HTTP-based Semantic Bank API that enables client applications to post to its RDF Triple Store, and several RDF insert methods, including http PUT and POST. Virtuoso SPARQL can use an inference context for inferring triples (not physically stored) by supporting some RDFS and OWL constraints (e.g., owl:sameAs, rdfs:subClassOf, rdfs:subPropertyOf, and others).
Virtoso also includes a faceted search interface out-of-the box which allows simple text search and navigation of RDF data through their links. 
Moreover Virtuoso includes Sponger, a Linked Data middleware component. It generates Linked Data from a variety of data sources, and supports a wide variety of data representation and serialization formats (e.g., standard non-rdf like csv, atom, rss, etc., and vendor-specific like facebook, google+, geonames, openstreetmap, etc.). The Sponger is also a full-fledged HTTP proxy service, directly accessible via SOAP or REST interfaces. Similarly, Virtuoso includes RDBMS-to-RDF mapping functionality (also known as, Linked Data Views of SQL data).
Test instance from FOODIE: https://www.foodie-cloud.org/sparql , DATABIO dedicated instance to be deployed
RDF and with Sponger a wide variety of data representation and serialisation formats
SPARQL, REST interface, Faceted search GUI
required: OS Linux - Centos7; optional: HDFS, SPARK

H2O is a statistical, machine learning and math runtime tool for bigdata analysis. Developed by the predictive analytics company H2O.ai, H2O has established a leadership in the ML scene together with R and Databricks’ Spark. According to the team,  H2O is the world’s fastest in-memory platform for machine learning and predictive analytics on big data. It is designed to help users scale machine learning, math, and statistics over large datasets.
API R, Python, Scala, Java, Excel, Tableau; REST API; WEB UI

The DSS is a tool supporting the application of the general principles of integrated pest management by all professional users of plant protection products, obligatory for the EU member states since 1st January 2014, as outlined in detail in the provisions of Art. 14 Directive 2009/128/EC and art. 55 of Regulation No 1107/2009/WE.
Such DSS is useful in determining the optimal terms of crop protection, and thus allow obtaining high efficiency of these treatments while reducing the use of chemical pesticides to a minimum. Accordingly, the IPM-DSS implements the following functionalities:
• Storage and management of users’ and agro-meteorological data that serve as the source for the DSS calculations, including: (i) users (farmers/advisors) data collected through the system interface; (ii) farms and crop data collected from the farmers’ inputs in the system; (iii) agro-meteorological data collected from the regional/national stations network. 
• Algorithms for the control of plant diseases in the form of a restful service. This service provides the vital information for farmers or agricultural advisors about the risks and the conditions conducive to the occurrence of diseases and pests. Currently, there are five algorithms implemented and tested: potato late blight, colorado potato beetle, Turnip moth on beet, Leaf Beetle on wheat, cercospora leaf spot on beets
• Presentation of data and calculation results from the plant diseases algorithms in the form of tables and graphs. 
• Presentation in a map of the current meteorological conditions collected from the stations network, and visualisation of the historical data.
• Notifications of personalized events to directly inform the recipient about the crossing of ex-ceeding limit of the defined threshold threats of the output
pest management, crop protection, notifications, plant diseases

PSNC is a leading HPC and cloud-computing center disposing of extensive ICT research infrastructure, including 1.5+ PFLOPS of computing power, and 47  PB storage  and  data  management  infrastructure.  The HPC/private  cloud  part consists of ~1070 servers (~15k cores, ~40TB RAM, 10 GE and In-finiBand fat-tree interconnects), the SAN consists of disk arrays (1.8 PB), tape libraries (3.7 PB) and various interconnects (FC, 1/10 GE, InfiniBand).

The (FOODIE) marketplace provides a virtual space to connect consumers and producers of agricultural data and applications. 
It enables farmers and other stakeholders to find and consume relevant resources in the agri-food domain, including datasets, services, applications, training materials, etc., by exposing flexible searching mechanisms and exploiting semantic technologies. These resources include both internal resources (in the underlying marketplace infrastructure), but also information and links to relevant resources, available externally, but collected and described in the marketplace. Similarly, the marketplace enables producers to publish their own datasets, services and applications. They are able to upload and deploy these resources directly to the underlying marketplace infrastruture or to provide an URL to an external source.
Moreover, the marketplace supports different access methods (free or payed) to support the dissemination and commercialisation of products, and implements different social features to enable the collaboration between users in the community.
